group_1.narration: I visited the professor's research lab again,@with a newly-rewritten thesis in hand...

group_1.textRight: I see...
So you're saying the hill was originally a@zenpou-kouen-fun, as opposed to an enpun.

group_1.textLeft: Yes. I've written a list of sources cited as@evidence...

group_1.textRight: ...Another of Kamihama's traditional@manuscripts, I see.
I'm familiar with this one, too.@It's from the early Edo period,
But it's a reliable historical source for@records of natural disasters.
So there's something important in here, eh...?

group_1.textLeft: Yes. First, as we're both aware...
There's a river close to the hill with an old@bridge built across it.

group_1.textRight: Indeed.

group_1.textLeft: Which brings me to a particular passage I found@in this source.

group_1.textRight: ...Ah, here. Hmm.@"After several days of dense rains..."
"One of the twin hills finally collapsed"...?

group_1.textLeft: Then "the lost soil was carried away by the@flooded river"...
..."leaving one half of the hills as barren as@undeveloped land."

group_1.textRight: A very interesting passage indeed!
This brings us a step closer to the "former@zenpou-kouen-fun" theory.

group_1.textLeft: Does the phrase "twin hills" really refer to our@hill after all...?

group_1.textRight: Yes. That's the next point of interest.
But... Oh, what's this?
Now that's a surprise! This text...
It describes the relative positions of the bridge@that was over the river at the time...
...And the "twin hills."
Your bibliographic survey was already extremely@precise, as of your last paper.
I suspect this excerpt is every bit as@trustworthy too.
...And the bridge is even in the same location@today, I see.
It's been rebuilt in the interim, but it's in@the exact same spot.
Hm... there's "a river one road across from the@foot of the hill" that was lost in the flood,
And "the bridge is built across it"...?
...With this many resources at our disposal, we@can determine its position quite precisely.
Let's take a look at today's map.
If we posit that the hill originally extended up@to the location of the bridge here...

group_1.textLeft: ...It forms the shape of a zenpou-kouen-fun, doesn't@it?

group_1.textRight: Quite possibly!@As do the roads and waterways surrounding it.
They're all indicating the former presence of@the kofun.

group_1.textLeft: When I saw those aerial photos, I just got this@sense that it was a kofun for some reason...

group_1.textRight: A keen observation! I imagine some scholars@must've thought the same thing.
The fact that none of them followed up on the@possibility of it being a zenpou-kouen-fun...
We experts must have been terribly lazy, eh?

group_1.textLeft: Do you think there's any merit in assessing the@hill...?

group_1.textRight: If you ask me? There's plenty!
There's just one problem, I'm afraid...
The budget for the bypass construction...
Passed through the city's budget committee just@yesterday.
Compared to finding it intact in a preliminary@assessment...
Finding a kofun in a damaged state after@construction starts...
Well, it's a lot less valuable from an@archaeological perspective.
There's still time before construction actually@begins.
So I, for one, hope to yell 'til I'm blue in the@face about the need to assess it...

group_1.textLeft: But as for whether they'll be able to excavate it@in time...?

group_1.textRight: If I'm to be completely honest with you...
It'll be difficult to make it a reality this@late in the game.
Not without outside help, at least.
